Linear DRO Methods

Chi-squared Distributionally Robust Optimization (chi2-DRO) model.

This model minimizes a chi-squared robust loss function for both regression and classification.

param input_dim:

Dimensionality of the input features.

type input_dim:

int

param model_type:

Model type indicator (e.g., ‘svm’ for SVM, ‘logistic’ for Logistic Regression, ‘ols’ for Linear Regression with L2-loss, ‘lad’ for Linear Regression with L1-loss).

type model_type:

str

param fit_intercept:

Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered).

type fit_intercept:

bool, default = True

param solver:

Optimization solver to solve the problem, default = ‘MOSEK’.

type solver:

str, default = ‘MOSEK’

param eps:

Robustness parameter for DRO.

type eps:

float

Reference: <https://www.jmlr.org/papers/volume20/17-750/17-750.pdf>

Conditional Value-at-Risk (CVaR) Distributionally Robust Optimization (DRO) model.

Y|X (ConditionalShiftBased) Conditional Value-at-Risk (Conditional-CVaR) Distributionally Robust Optimization (DRO) model that only allow likelihood ratio changes in Y|X.

This model minimizes a robust loss function for both regression and classification tasks under a CVaR constraint only for the distribution of Y|X.

Conditional CVaR DRO model following Theorem 2 in: with alpha(x) to be beta^T x for simplicity alpha corresponds to Gamma in the paper.

param input_dim:

Dimensionality of the input features.

type input_dim:

int

param model_type:

type model_type:

str

param alpha:

Risk level for CVaR.

type alpha:

float

param fit_intercept:

Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered).

type fit_intercept:

bool, default = True

param solver:

Optimization solver to solve the problem, default = ‘MOSEK’.

type solver:

str, default = ‘MOSEK’

param alpha:

Risk level for CVaR.

type alpha:

float, default = 1

param control_name:

Indices of the control features for conditional DRO.

type control_name:

Optional[list[int]]

Reference: <https://arxiv.org/pdf/2209.01754.pdf>

Marginal-X Conditional Value-at-Risk (Conditional-CVaR) Distributionally Robust Optimization (DRO) model that only allow likelihood ratio changes in X.

This model minimizes a robust loss function for both regression and classification tasks under a CVaR constraint only for the marginal distribution of X.

param input_dim:

Dimensionality of the input features.

type input_dim:

int

param model_type:

Type of model (e.g., ‘svm’, ‘logistic’, ‘ols’).

type model_type:

str

param alpha:

Risk level for CVaR.

type alpha:

float

param fit_intercept:

Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered).

type fit_intercept:

bool, default = True

param solver:

Optimization solver to solve the problem, default = ‘MOSEK’.

type solver:

str, default = ‘MOSEK’

param control_name:

Indices of the control features for marginal DRO.

type control_name:

Optional[list[int]]

param p:

Power parameter for the distance measure.

type p:

int

param L:

Scaling parameter for the marginal robustness.

type L:

float

param threshold_val:

Threshold value from the optimization.

type threshold_val:

float

Reference: [1] <https://pubsonline.informs.org/doi/10.1287/opre.2022.2363> [2] The specific model follows Equation (27) in: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2007.13982.pdf with parameters L and p.

OT discrepancy with conditional moment constraint, the cost is set as: c(((X_1, Y_1), w), ((X_2, Y_2), hat w)) = theta1 * w * d((X_1, Y_1), (X_2, Y_2)) + theta2 * (phi(w) - phi(hat w))^+, where phi() is the KL divergence.

param input_dim:

Dimensionality of the input features.

type input_dim:

int

param model_type:

Model type indicator (e.g., ‘svm’ for SVM, ‘logistic’ for Logistic Regression, ‘ols’ for Linear Regression with L2-loss, ‘lad’ for Linear Regression with L1-loss).

type model_type:

str

param eps:

Robustness parameter for DRO.

type eps:

float

param cost matrix:

the feature importance perturbation matrix with the dimension being (input_dim, input_dim).

type cost matrix:

np.ndarray

param p:

Norm parameter for controlling the perturbation moment of X.

type p:

float or ‘inf’

param theta1:

theta1 geq 0 controls the strength of Wasserstein Distance

type theta1:

float

param theta2:

theta2 geq 0 controls the strength of KL Divergence

type theta2:

float

Reference: <https://arxiv.org/abs/2308.05414>

Robust satisficing version of Wasserstein DRO

This model minimizes the subject to (approximated version) of the robust satisficing constraint of Wasserstein DRO. The Wasserstein Distance is defined as the minimum probability coupling of two distributions for the distance metric: d((X_1, Y_1), (X_2, Y_2)) = (abs(cost_matrix^{1/2} @ (X_1 - X_2))_p)^{square} + kappa abs(Y_1 - Y_2).

Dimensionality of the input features.

Type:

int

dro.src.linear_model.Wasserstein_DRO.Wasserstein_DRO_satisficing.model_type

Model type indicator (‘svm’ for SVM, ‘logistic’ for Logistic Regression, ‘ols’ for Linear Regression for OLS, ‘lad’ for Linear Regression for LAD), default=’svm’.

Type:

str

Reference: <https://pubsonline.informs.org/doi/10.1287/opre.2021.2238>

Wasserstein Distributionally Robust Optimization (WDRO) model

This model minimizes a Wasserstein-robust loss function for both regression and classification.

The Wasserstein distance is defined as the minimum probability coupling of two distributions for the distance metric:

d((X_1, Y_1), (X_2, Y_2)) = (abs(cost_matrix^{1/2} @ (X_1 - X_2))_p)^{square} + kappa abs(Y_1 - Y_2).

param input_dim:

Dimensionality of the input features.

type input_dim:

int

param model_type:

Model type indicator (‘svm’ for SVM, ‘logistic’ for Logistic Regression, ‘ols’ for Linear Regression for OLS, ‘lad’ for Linear Regression for LAD).

type model_type:

str, default = ‘svm’

param fit_intercept:

Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered).

type fit_intercept:

bool, default = True

param solver:

Optimization solver to solve the problem, default = ‘MOSEK’.

type solver:

str, default = ‘MOSEK’

param eps:

Robustness parameter for DRO.

type eps:

float

param cost matrix:

the feature importance perturbation matrix with the dimension being (input_dim, input_dim).

type cost matrix:

np.ndarray

param p:

Norm parameter for controlling the perturbation moment of X.

type p:

float or ‘inf’

param kappa:

Robustness parameter for the perturbation of Y. Note that if we set kappa to be large enough to approximately infinite, this is equivalent to saying that we do not allow changes in Y.

type kappa:

float or ‘inf’

Reference: [1] OLS: <https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-applied-probability/article/robust-wasserstein-profile-inference-and-applications-to-machine-learning/4024D05DE4681E67334E45D039295527> [2] LAD / SVM / Logistic: <https://jmlr.org/papers/volume20/17-633/17-633.pdf>
